node.contents: I was reading a book on programming skills wherein the author asks the interviewee, "How do you crash a JVM?" I thought that you could do so by writing an infinite for-loop that would eventually use up all the memory.

astNode.text: I was reading a book on programming skills wherein the author asks the interviewee, "How do you crash a JVM?" I thought that you could do so by writing an infinite for-loop that would eventually use up all the memory.

node.contents: Anybody has any idea?

elements.contents: public class Crash { public static void main(String[] args) { main(args); } }

node.contents: If you define a crash as an process abort because of a unhandled situation (i.e. no Java Exception or Error), then this can not be done from within Java. This the whole point of managed code.

astNode.text: If you define a crash as an process abort because of a unhandled situation (i.e. no Java Exception or Error), then this can not be done from within Java. This the whole point of managed code.

node.contents: Typical crashes in machine code happen by dereferencing pointers to wrong memory areas (null address or missaligned. Another source could be illegal machine instructions (opcodes) or unhandled signals from library or kernel calls.

astNode.text: Typical crashes in machine code happen by dereferencing pointers to wrong memory areas (null address or missaligned. Another source could be illegal machine instructions (opcodes) or unhandled signals from library or kernel calls.

node.contents: JVMs (the native code) can have bugs. For example JITed (generated) code, native methods or system calls (graphics driver) can have problems leading to real crashes. In those cases the crash handler of the JVM kicks in and dumps the state. It could also generate a OS core file (Dr. Watson on Windows and core dump on *nix).

astNode.text: JVMs (the native code) can have bugs. For example JITed (generated) code, native methods or system calls (graphics driver) can have problems leading to real crashes. In those cases the crash handler of the JVM kicks in and dumps the state. It could also generate a OS core file (Dr. Watson on Windows and core dump on *nix).

node.contents: On Linux/Unix you can easyly make a JVM crash by sending it a Signal to the running process. Note: you should not use SIGSEGV for this, since Hotspot catches this signal and re-throws it as a NullPointerException in most places. So it is better to send a SIGBUS for example.

astNode.text: On Linux/Unix you can easyly make a JVM crash by sending it a Signal to the running process. Note: you should not use SIGSEGV for this, since Hotspot catches this signal and re-throws it as a NullPointerException in most places. So it is better to send a SIGBUS for example.

node.contents: I wouldn't call throwing an OutOfMemoryError or StackOverflowError a crash. These are just normal exceptions. To really crash a VM there are 3 ways:

astNode.text: I wouldn't call throwing an OutOfMemoryError or StackOverflowError a crash. These are just normal exceptions. To really crash a VM there are 3 ways:

node.contents:
1. Use JNI and crash in the native code.
  2. If no security manager is installed you can use reflection to crash the VM. This is VM specific, but normally a VM stores a bunch of pointers to native resources in private fields (e.g. a pointer to the native thread object is stored in a long field in java.lang.Thread). Just change them via reflection and the VM will crash sooner or later.
  3. All VMs have bugs, so you just have to trigger one.

astNode.text:
1. Use JNI and crash in the native code.
  2. If no security manager is installed you can use reflection to crash the VM. This is VM specific, but normally a VM stores a bunch of pointers to native resources in private fields (e.g. a pointer to the native thread object is stored in a long field in java.lang.Thread). Just change them via reflection and the VM will crash sooner or later.
  3. All VMs have bugs, so you just have to trigger one.

node.contents: For the last method I have a short example, which will crash a Sun Hotspot VM quiet nicely:

astNode.text: For the last method I have a short example, which will crash a Sun Hotspot VM quiet nicely:

elements.contents: public class Crash { public static void main(String[] args) { Object[] o = null; while (true) { o = new Object[] {o}; } } }

units.rawText: public class Crash { public static void main(String[] args) { Object[] o = null; while (true) { o = new Object[] {o}; } } }

node.contents: This leads to a stack overflow in the GC so you will get no StackOverflowError but a real crash including a hs_err* file.

astNode.text: This leads to a stack overflow in the GC so you will get no StackOverflowError but a real crash including a hs_err* file.

node.contents: Depends on what you mean by crash.

astNode.text: Depends on what you mean by crash.

node.contents: You can do an infinite recursion to make it run out of stack space, but that'll crash "gracefully". You'll get an exception, but the JVM itself will be handling everything.

astNode.text: You can do an infinite recursion to make it run out of stack space, but that'll crash "gracefully". You'll get an exception, but the JVM itself will be handling everything.

node.contents: You can also use JNI to call native code. If you don't do it just right then you can make it crash hard. Debugging those crashes is "fun" (trust me, I had to write a big C++ DLL that we call from a signed java applet). :)

astNode.text: You can also use JNI to call native code. If you don't do it just right then you can make it crash hard. Debugging those crashes is "fun" (trust me, I had to write a big C++ DLL that we call from a signed java applet). :)

elements.contents: public class Recur { public static void main(String[] argv) { try { recur(); } catch (Error e) { System.out.println(e.toString()); } System.out.println("Ended normally"); } static void recur() { Object[] o = null; try { while(true) { Object[] newO = new Object[1]; newO[0] = o; o = newO; } } finally { recur(); } } }

units.rawText: public class Recur { public static void main(String[] argv) { try { recur(); } catch (Error e) { System.out.println(e.toString()); } System.out.println("Ended normally"); } static void recur() { Object[] o = null; try { while(true) { Object[] newO = new Object[1]; newO[0] = o; o = newO; } } finally { recur(); } } }

node.contents: Instead of using -Xbootclasspath you can also just do this: `Field f = Unsafe.class.getDeclaredField( "theUnsafe" ); f.setAccessible( true ); unsafe = (Unsafe) f.get( null );` Worked great for me.

astNode.text: Instead of using -Xbootclasspath you can also just do this: `Field f = Unsafe.class.getDeclaredField( "theUnsafe" ); f.setAccessible( true ); unsafe = (Unsafe) f.get( null );` Worked great for me.

node.contents: Use this:

astNode.text: Use this:

elements.contents: import sun.misc.Unsafe; public class Crash { private static final Unsafe unsafe = Unsafe.getUnsafe(); public static void crash() { unsafe.putAddress(0, 0); } public static void main(String[] args) { crash(); } }

units.rawText: import sun.misc.Unsafe; public class Crash { private static final Unsafe unsafe = Unsafe.getUnsafe(); public static void crash() { unsafe.putAddress(0, 0); } public static void main(String[] args) { crash(); } }

node.contents: This class must be on the boot classpath because it is using trusted code,so run like this:

astNode.text: This class must be on the boot classpath because it is using trusted code,so run like this:

node.contents: java -Xbootclasspath/p:. Crash

astNode.text: java -Xbootclasspath/p:. Crash

node.contents: A perfect JVM implementation will never crash.

astNode.text: A perfect JVM implementation will never crash.

node.contents: To crash a JVM, aside from JNI, you need to find a bug in the VM itself. An infinite loop just consumes CPU. Infinitely allocating memory should just cause OutOfMemoryError's in a well built JVM. This would probably cause problems for other threads, but a good JVM still should not crash.

astNode.text: To crash a JVM, aside from JNI, you need to find a bug in the VM itself. An infinite loop just consumes CPU. Infinitely allocating memory should just cause OutOfMemoryError's in a well built JVM. This would probably cause problems for other threads, but a good JVM still should not crash.

node.contents: If you can find a bug in the source code of the VM, and for example cause a segmentation fault in the memory usage of the implementation of the VM, then you can actually crash it.

astNode.text: If you can find a bug in the source code of the VM, and for example cause a segmentation fault in the memory usage of the implementation of the VM, then you can actually crash it.

node.contents: JNI is a large source of crashes. You can also crash using the JVMTI interface since that needs to be written in C/C++ as well.

astNode.text: JNI is a large source of crashes. You can also crash using the JVMTI interface since that needs to be written in C/C++ as well.

node.contents: Such interview questions serve as litmus tests for Java developers that have been around long enough to 1) have witnessed (many) JVM crashes and 2) have drawn some conclusions or, better yet, as (self-proclaimed) Java experts have tried understanding the underlying reasons for a crash. Chad Fowler also states in his book that self-proclaimed Java programmers "couldn't even come up with the wrong answer", i.e. haven't tried thinking about when a whole class of potential problems. The bottom line: this question is segway to "How to prevent JVM crashes?" which is clearly even better to know.

astNode.text: Such interview questions serve as litmus tests for Java developers that have been around long enough to 1) have witnessed (many) JVM crashes and 2) have drawn some conclusions or, better yet, as (self-proclaimed) Java experts have tried understanding the underlying reasons for a crash. Chad Fowler also states in his book that self-proclaimed Java programmers "couldn't even come up with the wrong answer", i.e. haven't tried thinking about when a whole class of potential problems. The bottom line: this question is segway to "How to prevent JVM crashes?" which is clearly even better to know.

node.contents: I came here because I also ran into this question in The Passionate Programmer, by Chad Fowler. For those who don't have access to a copy, the question is framed as a kind of filter/test for candidates interviewing for a position requiring "really good Java programmers."

astNode.text: I came here because I also ran into this question in The Passionate Programmer, by Chad Fowler. For those who don't have access to a copy, the question is framed as a kind of filter/test for candidates interviewing for a position requiring "really good Java programmers."

node.contents: Specifically, he asks:

astNode.text: Specifically, he asks:

node.contents: How would you write a program, in pure Java, that would cause the Java Virtual Machine to crash?

astNode.text: How would you write a program, in pure Java, that would cause the Java Virtual Machine to crash?

node.contents: I've programmed in Java for over 15 years, and I found this question to be both puzzling and unfair. As others have pointed out, Java, as a managed language, is specifically designed not to crash. Of course there are always JVM bugs, but:

astNode.text: I've programmed in Java for over 15 years, and I found this question to be both puzzling and unfair. As others have pointed out, Java, as a managed language, is specifically designed not to crash. Of course there are always JVM bugs, but:

node.contents:
1. After 15+ years of production-level JREs, it's rare.
  2. Any such bugs are likely to be patched in the next release, so how likely are you as a programmer to run into and recall the details of the current set of JRE show-stoppers?

astNode.text:
1. After 15+ years of production-level JREs, it's rare.
  2. Any such bugs are likely to be patched in the next release, so how likely are you as a programmer to run into and recall the details of the current set of JRE show-stoppers?

node.contents: As others have mentioned, some native code via JNI is a sure way to crash a JRE. But the author specifically mentioned in pure Java, so that's out.

astNode.text: As others have mentioned, some native code via JNI is a sure way to crash a JRE. But the author specifically mentioned in pure Java, so that's out.

node.contents: Another option would be to feed the JRE bogus byte codes; it's easy enough to dump some garbage binary data to a .class file, and ask the JRE to run it:

astNode.text: Another option would be to feed the JRE bogus byte codes; it's easy enough to dump some garbage binary data to a .class file, and ask the JRE to run it:

elements.contents: $ echo 'crap crap crap' > crap.class $ java crap Exception in thread "main" java.lang.ClassFormatError: Incompatible magic value 1668440432 in class file crap

fragments.message: Incompatible magic value 1668440432 in class file crap

units.rawText: $ echo 'crap crap crap' > crap.class $ java crap Exception in thread "main" java.lang.ClassFormatError:Incompatible magic value 1668440432 in class file crap

node.contents: Does that count? I mean the JRE itself hasn't crashed; it properly detected the bogus code, reported it, and exited.

astNode.text: Does that count? I mean the JRE itself hasn't crashed; it properly detected the bogus code, reported it, and exited.

node.contents: This leaves us with the most obvious kinds of solutions such as blowing the stack via recursion, running out of heap memory via object allocations, or simply throwing RuntimeException. But this just causes the JRE to exit with a StackOverflowError or similar exception, which, again is not really a crash.

astNode.text: This leaves us with the most obvious kinds of solutions such as blowing the stack via recursion, running out of heap memory via object allocations, or simply throwing RuntimeException. But this just causes the JRE to exit with a StackOverflowError or similar exception, which, again is not really a crash.

node.contents: So what's left? I'd really love to hear what the author really had in mind as a proper solution.

astNode.text: So what's left? I'd really love to hear what the author really had in mind as a proper solution.

node.contents: JNI. In fact, with JNI, crashing is the default mode of operation. You have to work extra hard to get it not to crash.

astNode.text: JNI. In fact, with JNI, crashing is the default mode of operation. You have to work extra hard to get it not to crash.

node.contents: Broken hardware can crash any program. I once had an app crash reproducably on a specific machine while running fine on other machines with the exact same setup. Turns out that machine had faulty RAM.

astNode.text: Broken hardware can crash any program. I once had an app crash reproducably on a specific machine while running fine on other machines with the exact same setup. Turns out that machine had faulty RAM.

node.contents: without proper cleanup? are you sure? The documentation says "Terminates the currently running Java virtual machine by initiating its shutdown sequence ... all registered shutdown hooks, if any, are started ... all uninvoked finalizers are run" - isn't that the proper cleanup?

astNode.text: without proper cleanup? are you sure? The documentation says "Terminates the currently running Java virtual machine by initiating its shutdown sequence ... all registered shutdown hooks, if any, are started ... all uninvoked finalizers are run" - isn't that the proper cleanup?

node.contents: This isn't crashing the JVM, it's purposefully and explicitly beginning an orderly shut-down of execution.

astNode.text: This isn't crashing the JVM, it's purposefully and explicitly beginning an orderly shut-down of execution.

node.contents: Closer to crashing the jvm is Runtime.getRuntime().halt( status ). According to the docs "this method does not cause shutdown hooks to be started and does not run uninvoked finalizers if finalization-on-exit has been enabled". Still not a crash, but closer than System.exit.

astNode.text: Closer to crashing the jvm is Runtime.getRuntime().halt( status ). According to the docs "this method does not cause shutdown hooks to be started and does not run uninvoked finalizers if finalization-on-exit has been enabled". Still not a crash, but closer than System.exit.

node.contents: This is really a bad answer.

astNode.text: This is really a bad answer.

node.contents: The closest thing to a single "answer" is System.exit() which terminates the JVM immediately without proper cleanup. But apart from that, native code and resource exhaustion are the most likely answers. Alternatively you can go looking on Sun's bug tracker for bugs in your version of the JVM, some of which allow for repeatable crash scenarios. We used to get semi-regular crashes when approaching the 4 Gb memory limit under the 32-bit versions (we generally use 64-bit now).

astNode.text: The closest thing to a single "answer" is System.exit() which terminates the JVM immediately without proper cleanup. But apart from that, native code and resource exhaustion are the most likely answers. Alternatively you can go looking on Sun's bug tracker for bugs in your version of the JVM, some of which allow for repeatable crash scenarios. We used to get semi-regular crashes when approaching the 4 Gb memory limit under the 32-bit versions (we generally use 64-bit now).
